results.headline: Death Reclaims His Fractured Psyche
results.summary_short: “My Soul to Take” has the comic pop-culture references and dreamy shocks of a Wes Craven film, but the director’s heart does not seem to be into it.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of My Soul to Take

results.headline: Loose Connections That Lead to Horror
results.summary_short: In “Red White & Blue,” Amanda Fuller plays an aimless young woman whose poor choice in one-night stands catches up with her.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Red White & Blue

results.headline: Model Town as Safe Haven
results.summary_short: Jeff Malmberg’s “Marwencol” shows how an artist recovering from an assault uses a fantasy world to heal himself.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Marwencol

results.headline: Who Maimed the Economy, and How
results.summary_short: Charles Ferguson’s documentary looks at the origins of the 2008 financial crisis.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Inside Job

results.headline: Death by Chicken Tikka, in Service of Romance
results.summary_short: One mother puts reincarnation — both hers and her murder victims’ — on hold to find her daughter a husband in Gurinder Chadha’s “It’s a Wonderful Afterlife.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of It's a Wonderful Afterlife

results.headline: More Sex, Please, We’re British Rustics
results.summary_short: In “Tamara Drewe,” directed by Stephen Frears, a comely newspaper columnist returns home to a rural village, where suitors abound.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tamara Drewe

results.headline: Upright Parole Officer With a Target on His Back
results.summary_short: Edward Norton and Robert De Niro star in “Stone,” the director John Curran’s brooding, low-key intrigue with strokes of film noir.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Stone

results.headline: An Exploitation Film, Remade
results.summary_short: Sarah Butler is the victim who exacts revenge on her attackers in “I Spit on Your Grave.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of I Spit On Your Grave

results.headline: Putting Faith in Speed and Sinew
results.summary_short: Diane Lane plays the racehorse owner Penny Chenery in “Secretariat,” an inspirational Disney film that is squeaky clean and as square as a military flattop.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Secretariat

results.headline: Examining an Activist’s Death
results.summary_short: “Rachel” documents the life and death of Rachel Corrie, the young American defender of Palestinian rights.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Rachel

results.headline: Lennon’s Teenage Years: Rocking and Roiling
results.summary_short: Sam Taylor-Wood’s “Nowhere Boy” delves into a tumultuous period in his life, when he sought maternal love and artistic freedom.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Nowhere Boy

results.headline: Finding Love Over Dirty Diapers and Sippy Cups
results.summary_short: “Life as We Know It,” with Katherine Heigl and Josh Duhamel, never deviates from the romantic-comedy formula, but is well made for its corporate type.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Life As We Know It

results.headline: The Ex-Con and the Priest
results.summary_short: In Klaus Haro’s “Letters to Father Jacob,” a young Finnish woman just out of prison finds work helping an aging pastor.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Postia pappi Jaakobille

results.headline: Science Fiction for the Great Recession
results.summary_short: In “Jim,” Jeremy Morris-Burke has written and directed a downsizing drama that overlaps with a cautionary tale about genetic engineering linked to a dystopian future.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Jim

results.headline: Visiting New York, Seeking Vengeance
results.summary_short: Andie MacDowell and Frank Whaley hold Cary Elwes hostage for a crime they believe he committed in “As Good as Dead.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of As Good As Dead

results.headline: Preparing for Sightlessness
results.summary_short: In “Going Blind,” the director Joseph Lovett confronts the onset of his own loss of vision.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Going Blind

results.headline: A Coming-of-Age Tale, Set Among the Sad
results.summary_short: An adaptation of Ned Vizzini’s novel “It’s Kind of a Funny Story” stars Zach Galifianakis and Keir Gilchrist.
results.display_title: It's Kind of a Funny Story

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of It's Kind of a Funny Story

results.headline: A Study in Middle East Nonviolence
results.summary_short: Julia Bacha’s “Budrus” looks at how one West Bank town took on the Israeli military.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Budrus

results.headline: Misanthrope Sprouts Wings and Humanity
results.summary_short: “Idiots and Angels,” the new animated film by Bill Plympton, creates a dystopia that suggests Toulouse-Lautrec by way of Charles Bukowski.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Idiots and Angels

results.headline: Another Argument Against E-Mail
results.summary_short: “Chain Letter,” a horror film directed by Deon Taylor, focuses on a risk associated with electronic messaging that has nothing to do with distracted driving.
